body:
Too much truth to this. Feels like all (most?) of the hobby guilds I've been following have been losing activity, while everyone is currently celebrating growth in traffic. Yet we constantly see "Not enough non-political content" and "Be the change you want to see" being thrown around.

Seems like a ton of people want more of it, but have no idea what to contribute or how, while we're slowly bleeding away the ones who do.

Too much truth to this. Feels like all (most?) of the hobby guilds I've been following have been losing activity, while everyone is currently celebrating growth in traffic. Yet we constantly see "Not enough non-political content" and "Be the change you want to see" being thrown around.

body: When politics has been pushed into so much media and hobbies with both extremes it really does make filtering and curating quality non-political content take longer. It's far easier and lazier to make a post with some link to a news article or video than spending time constructing a post on hobby best practices. Take podcasts for example; good luck finding a series that doesn't talk about politics atm. It's rare and quickly drowned out by the majority that do. We live in the post-effort internet age were users want content feed to them versus looking for hours or days to find something different. Isn't* that the reason why multi 'forum' like sites such as ruqqus and reddit exist after all?
body_html: When politics has been pushed into so much media and hobbies with both extremes it really does make filtering and curating quality non-political content take longer. It's far easier and lazier to make a post with some link to a news article or video than spending time constructing a post on hobby best practices. Take podcasts for example; good luck finding a series that doesn't talk about politics atm. It's rare and quickly drowned out by the majority that do. We live in the post-effort internet age were users want content feed to them versus looking for hours or days to find something different. Isn't* that the reason why multi 'forum' like sites such as ruqqus and reddit exist after all?

parent.body:
Too much truth to this. Feels like all (most?) of the hobby guilds I've been following have been losing activity, while everyone is currently celebrating growth in traffic. Yet we constantly see "Not enough non-political content" and "Be the change you want to see" being thrown around.

Seems like a ton of people want more of it, but have no idea what to contribute or how, while we're slowly bleeding away the ones who do.

body: I have 3 guilds. 1 person posts on 1 of them--who is not a mod. That's it. I've pretty much given up on it. I have a job, too. I work 12 hour shifts. I don't have time to scour the internet every single day for hours looking for something interesting to get all of 4 upvotes from my entire 50 subscribers. I go there, make sure no one is posting anything they shouldn't (politics) once a day and then leave and don't go back. Why? If you're not going to participate, why should I? Its like sitting in silence refusing to give the waitress your order, then whinging no one brought you food. If you want more content, contribute more content. That is all

parent.body: When politics has been pushed into so much media and hobbies with both extremes it really does make filtering and curating quality non-political content take longer. It's far easier and lazier to make a post with some link to a news article or video than spending time constructing a post on hobby best practices. Take podcasts for example; good luck finding a series that doesn't talk about politics atm. It's rare and quickly drowned out by the majority that do. We live in the post-effort internet age were users want content feed to them versus looking for hours or days to find something different. Isn't* that the reason why multi 'forum' like sites such as ruqqus and reddit exist after all?
parent.body_html: When politics has been pushed into so much media and hobbies with both extremes it really does make filtering and curating quality non-political content take longer. It's far easier and lazier to make a post with some link to a news article or video than spending time constructing a post on hobby best practices. Take podcasts for example; good luck finding a series that doesn't talk about politics atm. It's rare and quickly drowned out by the majority that do. We live in the post-effort internet age were users want content feed to them versus looking for hours or days to find something different. Isn't* that the reason why multi 'forum' like sites such as ruqqus and reddit exist after all?
